name: Nicole Cano
tech: Javascript, Backbone, Parse, SCSS, HTML. Future implementation of Stripe.
rationale: I wanted to create a website for a friend of mine who is a stunt man, stunt coordinator and stunt trainer in the film industry. This website will make it easier for people to find out about him and the services he offers. Visitors will not only be able to view information such as filmography, videos, and pictures, but also find out about training workshops and register and pay for them via the website.

name: Phil Marshall
tech:
APIs - Parse | Paypal

HTML5, SCSS, JavaScript, JQuery, Bootstrap, Backbone
rationale: As a developer, I'm passionate about helping small businesses and brands transform their realities. This means leading stakeholders through the process of incorporating new and innovative technologies into their operations. Metro Retro is perhaps the largest dealer of vintage Mid Century furniture in the United States. They needed a sharp looking and nimble website, with specific administrative capabilities, in order to better serve the global high end marketplace.

name: Chris Lor
tech: HTML5 geolocation API, google maps API, pubnub SDK (for chatroom), HTML5, CSS3, SASS, MOCHA, CHAI, BACKBONEJS, REACT, JQUERY, AUTOPREFIXER, LODASH, LOCALSTORAGE, HEROKU, JSONP, JAVASCRIPT, TRELLO, SCRUM
rationale: Immediacy for gathering others with the same interests, specifically technology and programming-wise, into a chatroom around your current location; it also allows you to check meetups around your current location so you can plan and group with others in the chatroom to go together all on one page.

name: Dorsh Deans
tech: HTML, CSS, JS, Jquery, Backbone, Parse, Mocha, Chai, Google Maps API, Twitter API, Facebook API
rationale: As a life long Footballer (Soccer Player), I love nothing more than to play the game anywhere I am. I felt compelled to make an app that people can find "pick-up" soccer games in their area to play in!

name: Rafael Quijada
tech: HTML5, CSS3, SASS, BACKBONE JS, JQUERY, LODASH, HEROKU, JAVASCRIPT, TRELLO, SCRUM, NPM, LOADER, MOCHA, CHAI, LOCALSTORAGE, GOOGLE MAPS API, BREWERYDB API, FORECAST.IO, HTML5 GEOLOCATION API, JSONP
rationale: I wanted to create an app that would allow users to discover the different breweries out there as well as facilitate the planning process to visit them. So Beercast appeared, a webApp that allows you to search for breweries by location and get the details for that brewery alongside the weather for that area. This way you can plan the day around the brewery of your choice. Happy drinking!

name: VItaliy Dolbilov
tech:
Javascript , React/JSNoX , Jquery , lodash , Stripe , Rails , CORS , RESTful API,  Backbone , Highcharts , PDF.js , 

Square Reader, OmniAuth, Ruby Geocoder, HTML5 Geolocation, Rails Unobtrusive JS, leaflet.js, postgresql,   Heroku
rationale: Our goal is to create a lightweight, and flexible restaurant point of sale system that gets out of your way and lets you do what you really love.  It will have the widest possible range of hardware compliance and platform independence.  This makes it ideal for small restaurants, those just starting out, caterers, and my personal favorite- Houston's amazing food trucks.  With a rich API underway 3rd party add-ons will have easy access to support the many up and coming industry related startups that Houston is quickly becoming known for. In addition, we have a supplementary web app for customers, where they can log in, view restaurants using our system, and add their credit card info which can then be used to pay their order from the POS system. This allows for easier implementing of rewards programs and promotions - http://restaurant-ly.herokuapp.com/

name: Spencer Norman
tech: HTML5, SCSS, JAVASCRIPT, JQUERY, UNDERSCORE.JS, BOOTSTRAP, FORECAST.IO API, NAVIONICS API, RUBY ON RAILS, DEVISE, GEOCODER, AWS, ACTIVE MODEL, POSTGRES
rationale: A lot of anglers like to keep a log of their fishing trips for reference. I couldn’t find a decent application that made this experience very helpful or easy. So, I decided to make this a digital process and one that would help me on my future fishing trips. Fish respond to weather conditions in different ways. A lot of people have theories on what they do but I wanted to personalize it. A major part of this application allows you log the previous 4 days of weather leading up to the day that you went fishing and the day of that trip. The application then allows you to filter your trips based on the same information for an upcoming trip. This allows you to see how, individually, you fish best in those conditions. You can also record the water conditions and add your own notes to the trips so that you can easily reference these items.

name: Ben Magnant Brown
tech: React & Alt (a flux implementation) // Node & Express // Parse & Flickr API // npm & Browserify // ES6 & Babel // Testing via Mocha, Chai & jsdom // Scss
rationale: Cityscape represents an approach to serving the best results for diverse user interests. Cityscape creates a portal for city architecture nerds to find photos they want to see most. The voting system integrates with search to give unique rankings in every result. Active search terms are directly connected to each vote. Searches give users smart, weighted rankings that reflect what other users voted in the same search. Cityscape connects you to the city architecture photos and interests that you care about most.

name: Michael Padon
tech: HTML5, CSS3, SASS, JAVASCRIPT, REACT, JSNOX (INSTEAD OF JSX), PARSE (AND PARSE CLOUD CODE), STRIPE CREDIT CARD PROCESSING, BACKBONE, MOCHA, CHAI, BOWER, NPM, LOADER, AND JQUERY
rationale: The Maker movement is empowering people worldwide to go out and make things, from websites to tables to jewelry. It's awesome, but these makers sometimes lack the equipment required to make the cool things they want to make. Enter the Makerspace: a warehouse of equipment that members pay a monthly fee to use. These spaces are hubs for full-time artists, part-time hobbyists, and general enthusiasts that like to buy local, handmade stuff. Makerspaces can enable makers to actually make money off their craft, but it's often hard for a consumer, who wants to hire or buy from a local maker, to figure out who the Makerspace members are and what they are capable of creating. The current system is a hodgepodge of member databases, spreadsheets, and business cards on a table. It's hard to point an interested client in the direction of the right maker. In comes MakerBoard. It's an online board for Makerspaces where members can post their profile and customers can get in contact with the right person for their job. It takes all of the guess work out of finding capable makers for jobs.

name: Justin McKelvey
tech: Ruby, Rails, Git, Github, HTTP, JSON, HTML, CSS, Javascript, Heroku, Google geocoder API, Forecast IO API, Google flights API, CarrierWave, FOG, AWS / S3, Bootstrap, PG_search, Kaminari, Paginate, Rails_admin, Rake, Postgres, Action Mailer
rationale:
Do you love snow? I love snowboarding and when I have the opportunity to be in the mountains I want to make sure my time is spent in the most snow possible. I created an app that ranks projected snowfall for the upcoming week, from greatest to least. Once I've narrowed down my top resort or two, I linked the cheapest flight possible to get there leaving tomorrow! You can be on the best snow in North America ...tomorrow! 

“Would you like weekly snow updates? … submit your email and they’re on the way!”

name: LeRoy Gardner
tech: The technology used is Ruby, Rails, HTML, CSS, Stripe, PostgreSQL, JAVASCRIPT
rationale:
LiftWhen - A Focus On The Platform: State of the industry in the administration and running of an Olympic Weightlifting competition involves index cards and Microsoft Excel. Broken.

My application moves this administration, record keeping and information display from the table top with index cards to modernity. We allow the admin to focus on saving time, data integrity and communication. We allow coaches to focus on coaching not counting. We help fans cheer by enabling ease of information reporting. Finally we help athletes focus on lifting. We bring the sport back to a focus on the performance on the platform. 

I developed this application using my experience as a certified USA Weightlifting coach and competitor. It was painful as coach counting reps, competitors and estimating timelines for my athletes performance. Information was hard to come by. It was painful helping meet organizers enter results which were hand written on an index card into a spreadsheet. Results were slow to be publish, because of faxes, snail mailing and emails. Payment was painful because checks. 

In short we make it easier for meet organizers to run a successful meet, and report results.

name: Jonathan Harper
tech: i used Backbone/Parse, JavaScript, node, Lo-dash, CSS, rotten API's, Bower loader, and Chrome Dev tools.
rationale: I created my What to Watch? app for a couple of reasons. first let me start by asking have you ever wanted to watch a movie but you didn't know what one? i know i have, so the first reason i created this app was to have a bunch of movie titles all in one place that i could look through. The second reason i created this app was to view info on the movies before i watched them to help minimize the "what did i just watch?" factor.

name: Danny Sun
tech: Ruby on Rails, HTML5, CSS3, HighCharts, Postgres, JQuery
rationale: I wanted to create a resource for teachers that would enable them to grade their students' assignments but also track their progress as well. In doing this I felt it would naturally allow teachers to not only visualize aggregated data but also allow them to alter their respective curriculums. GradeU forces the next progression in the ability to teach as it serves to enhance both teacher and student's learning experiences.

name: Kristen Williams
tech: HTML5, CSS3, SCSS, JavaScript, Backbone.js, Parse, npm, Github pages, Git, loader.js, Pace.js, lodash, Bootstrap, Font Awesome, package.json scripts
rationale: CliniScheduler provides a quick and convenient way to request clinic visits online. Additionally, patients have a log of their prior and future visits that they may reference. Within each logged visit account, they may record notes prior to, during, and after their visit. These visit accounts may also be updated with advice, information, and orders from the physician/healthcare provider.
